thread.title: Halftime deficits too much for APSU football
thread.title_full: Halftime deficits too much for APSU football

title: Halftime deficits too much for APSU football
text:
Halftime deficits too much for APSU football Autumn Allison, aallison@theleafchronicle.com 9:44 p.m. CDT October 17, 2015 Quarterback Trey Taylor starts to look for open receivers in the loss to UT Martin on Oct. 17. (Photo: Autumn Allison/The Leaf-Chronicle) 7 CONNECT 2 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Buy Photo Wide Receiver Rashaan Coleman gets knocked during the Governors' loss to UT Martin on Oct. 17. Autumn Allison/The Leaf-Chronicle Buy Photo The Governors' offensive line readies for a play during the loss to UT Martin on Oct. 17. Autumn Allison/The Leaf-Chronicle Fullscreen Buy Photo Jared Beard shows his displeasure after a would-have-been touchdown pass was knocked away in the loss to UT Martin on Oct. 17. Autumn Allison/The Leaf-Chronicle Julian Franklin rushes for APSU's first touchdown in the loss to UT Martin on Oct. 17. Autumn Allison/The Leaf-Chronicle Players celebrate Julian Franklin's touchdown run in the loss to UT Martin on Oct. 17 Autumn Allison/The Leaf-Chronicle Fullscreen Buy Photo Taye Davis starts to go down in the second quarter of the loss to UT Martin on Oct. 17. Autumn Allison/The Leaf-Chronicle Rashaan Coleman gets taken down in the loss to UT Martin on Oct. 17. Autumn Allison/The Leaf-Chronicle Julian Franklin is tackled by two UT Martin defenders in the Govs' loss on Oct. 17. Autumn Allison/The Leaf-Chronicle Fullscreen Buy Photo Rashaan Coleman loses his footing in the second quarter of the loss to UT Martin on Oct. 17. Autumn Allison/The Leaf-Chronicle Fullscreen Buy Photo Nicholis Matiere-Bey attempts to take down UTM's Ladevin Fair in the loss to the Skyhawks on Oct. 17. Autumn Allison/The Leaf-Chronicle Buy Photo Kendall Morris attempts to fight off defenders early in the loss to UT Martin on Oct. 17. Autumn Allison/The Leaf-Chronicle Taye Davis gets forced out of bounds in the loss to UT Martin. Autumn Allison/The Leaf-Chronicle Defenders bring down Taye Davis in the APSU loss on Oct. 17. Autumn Allison/The Leaf-Chronicle Fullscreen Buy Photo Quarterback Trey Taylor starts to look for open receivers in the loss to UT Martin on Oct. 17. Autumn Allison/The Leaf-Chronicle Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Last Slide Next Slide 
CLARKSVILLE, Tenn.— Some holes are just too big to recover from, as Austin Peay football has discovered to its misfortune. 
Austin Peay (0-7, 0-4) fell to Ohio Valley Conference foe UT Martin 44-14 for the program’s 12th straight loss dating back to last season after falling behind 24 points at halftime. 
"It's frustrating because sometimes I feel we are a little shocked when we come out and play in the first half," said APSU line man Adam Noble. "And when we come out in the second half, even if they are playing the same players, we feel as if we can play with them." 
"I think we just need to get some guys ready to go right from the get off." 
After earning the OVC offensive player of the week honor last week, sophomore running back Kendall Morris was unable to match his two-game performance of 100-plus rushing yards after only securing 10 yards Saturday after a minor leg injury. Running backs Julian Franklin and Taye Davis, prior to his own small leg ding, had the majority of the Governors’ carries. 
"I think I responded good," said Franklin. "My last few games I got no carries, so it was a challenge coming in ... I always stay focused, I always go hard in practice because I know I will get an opportunity, and I've got to take advantage of it." 
Franklin led the team with 102 rushing yards and a touchdown. 
Just under two minutes into the game, the Skyhawks scored on a Jarod Neal to Caylon Weathers 22-yard pass. Trent Garland found the end zone with 7:25 on the clock to put UTM at 14-0. 
Near the end of the first quarter, Austin Peay was right within scoring range. UT Martin’s defense held strong and forced the Govs to try a field goal. 
Logan Birchfield’s attempt was blocked and then returned for an 84-yard touchdown by Jordan Landry as time ran out. 
APSU was able to final earn a touchdown in the second quarter when Franklin rushed for 37 yards to give the Governors their only score of the first half. What little gap that had been closed was flung wide open after Jackson Redditt nailed a 32-yard field goal and Garland ran in his second touchdown of the night for UTM’s 31-7 lead at halftime. 
"I think sometimes when you make some mistakes there is an easing into a game," said third-year coach Kirby Cannon. "Plus if they hit a play early then sometimes it makes everyone question what they are doing just for a moment or two." 
This was the fourth-straight game that the Governors were down by more than 20 points at the half. Last week’s loss to Murray State had the highest point differential with 25 points. 
In the third quarter, UT Martin’s machine of an offense slowed to a puttering rate with a failed PAT from Redditt and a called-back touchdown pass after a pass interference was called on the offense. Redditt followed the called-back touchdown with a field goal to give UTM the 34-7 lead. 
APSU found the end zone again after a quarterback change brought in Timarious Mitchell, who connected with Jared Beard for the 20-yard score. UTM would extend its lead once again on another Redditt field goal followed by a Jaimiee Bowe 17-yard run touchdown to give the final of 44-14. 
Saturday's win secured the Sgt. York Trophy, which goes to the Tennessee college in the OVC with the best record against the other OVC teams in the state, for UT Martin. 
The Governors' next game will be the Homecoming game against Jacksonville State on Oct. 24 at 4 p.m. 
Reach Autumn Allison at aallison@theleafchronicle.com or (931) 245-0248. Follow her on Twitter: @Aallison25. 7 CONNECT 2 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://leafne.ws/1ROVEoW TOP VIDEOS
